00002 #   Introducing Jython
00003 #
00004 
00005 #   Jython is a scripting language, so you can define variables easily:
00006 
00007 number = 12
00008 hello = "Hello"
00009 
00010 #to print:
00011 
00012 print hello
00013 print number
00014 print "Number is: " + `ten`
00015 
00016 #program control:
00017 
00018 for i in range(5):
00019         Thread.sleep(1000)  # this pauses the script for 1 second
00020         print i
00021 
00022 value = 10
00023 if (value == 10):
00024         print "value is 10"
00025 
00026 i = 0
00027 while i < 2:
00028         print i
00029         i += 1
00030 
00031 #    Note that you don't have to tell the script the start or end of the for loop with braces or and "end for" type statement
00032 #    Instead, the script knows what is inside the for-loop by the indentation of the lines
00033 #    You must use tabs to indent lines!
00034 
00035 # to create code for reuse, define a function using the def command:
00036 
00037 def myFunction():
00038         print "You've used my function!"
00039 
00040 myFunction()
00041 
00042 
00043 #    To use extra modules from Java, Jython or which you have written yourself, use the import command:
00044 
00045 import demo_module
00046 demo_module.myMethod()
00047 
00048 
00049 # namespaces:
00050 
00051 # scripts and the command-line on the Scripting Terminal tab have the same namespace,
00052 # so if you define an object or variable in one, you can access it from the other
00053
